interpret() Usage Patterns

Matthias Kloft

2025-11-23

Source: vignettes/articles/02-Usage_Patterns.qmd

Overview

This document demonstrates the different usage patterns for interpret(). The interpret() function is the main function of the psychinterpreter package and can be used in multiple ways. It will automatically detect the type of input provided and run the appropriate method for interpretation.

Setup

Packages

Code
packages <- c(
  "psychinterpreter",
  "ellmer",
  "ollamar",
  "psych",
  "lavaan",
  "mirt",
  "dplyr",
  "here",
  "DT",
  "pander"
)
# Load required packages using pacman
if (!require("pacman")) install.packages("pacman")
Loading required package: pacman
Code
pacman::p_load(char = packages)

Run Factor Analysis

Code
fa_model <- fa(mtcars[,1:4], nfactors = 2, rotate = "oblimin")

var_info <- data.frame(
  variable = c("mpg", "cyl", "disp", "hp"),
  description = c("Miles per gallon", "Cylinders", "Displacement", "Horsepower")
)

Usage Patterns

Pattern 1: Fitted Model Object

Set provider and model:

Code
provider <- "anthropic"
llm <- "claude-sonnet-4-5"

Automatically extracts model components from fitted objects.

Code
interpret(
  fit_results = fa_model,
  variable_info = var_info,
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,
  word_limit = 50
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Creating temporary chat session...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating fit summary...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

Loading cutoff: 0.3
LLM used: anthropic - claude-sonnet-4-5
Tokens:

  Output: 0
Elapsed time: 7.23

SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Factor 1 (84.1%): Engine Size and Performance
• Factor 2 (1.7%): Horsepower-Displacement Balance (n.s.)

Total variance explained: 85.8%

FACTOR CORRELATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

MR1: MR2 = .03
MR2: MR1 = .03

DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Factor 1 (MR1) - Engine Size and Performance
Number of significant loadings: 4
Variance explained: 84.05%
Factor Correlations: MR2 = .03

Variables:
  1. disp, Displacement (Positive, Very Strong, .955)
  2. cyl, Cylinders (Positive, Very Strong, .953)
  3. mpg, Miles per gallon (Negative, Very Strong, -.893)
  4. hp, Horsepower (Positive, Very Strong, .862)

LLM Interpretation:
This dominant factor captures engine specifications and power characteristics, with cylinders, displacement, and
horsepower loading strongly positive while fuel efficiency loads negative. It represents the fundamental trade-off
between larger, more powerful engines and fuel economy, explaining 84% of variance in these vehicle characteristics.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 2 (MR2) - Horsepower-Displacement Balance (n.s.)
Number of significant loadings: 0
Variance explained: 1.72%
Factor Correlations: MR1 = .03

WARNING: No variables load above cutoff (0.3). Emergency rule applied: using top 2 variable(s) below cutoff for
interpretation.

Variables:
  1. hp, Horsepower (Positive, Weak, .195)
  2. disp, Displacement (Negative, Weak, -.172)

LLM Interpretation:
This minor factor distinguishes horsepower from displacement, suggesting power output variations independent of engine
size. The positive horsepower loading contrasts with negative displacement, capturing efficiency in power generation.
Near-zero correlation with MR1 confirms discriminant validity, representing a distinct performance dimension beyond
overall engine size.

Pattern 2: Structured List

For custom data structures or manual extraction.

For FA, provide loadings (required) and optionally factor_cor_mat:

Code
loadings_matrix <- fa_model$loadings
factor_cor_mat <- fa_model$Phi

interpret(
  fit_results = list(loadings = loadings_matrix, factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat),
  variable_info = var_info,
  analysis_type = "fa",
  llm_provider = provider,
  llm_model = llm,
  word_limit = 50
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Creating temporary chat session...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating fit summary...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

FACTOR ANALYSIS INTERPRETATION
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Number of factors: 2
Loading cutoff: 0.3
LLM used: anthropic - claude-sonnet-4-5
Tokens:
  Input: 0
  Output: 0
Elapsed time: 8.56

SUGGESTED FACTOR NAMES
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

• Factor 1 (84%): Engine Size and Power
• Factor 2 (1.7%): Fuel Efficiency Residual (n.s.)

Total variance explained: 85.7%

FACTOR CORRELATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

MR1: MR2 = .03
MR2: MR1 = .03

DETAILED FACTOR INTERPRETATIONS
────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

Factor 1 (MR1) - Engine Size and Power
Number of significant loadings: 4
Variance explained: 84.03%
Factor Correlations: MR2 = .03

Variables:
  1. disp, Displacement (Positive, Very Strong, .955)
  2. cyl, Cylinders (Positive, Very Strong, .953)
  3. mpg, Miles per gallon (Negative, Very Strong, -.893)
  4. hp, Horsepower (Positive, Very Strong, .862)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor represents overall engine characteristics and vehicle power. High loadings on cylinders, displacement, and
horsepower reflect engine size and capacity, while the strong negative loading on fuel efficiency (mpg) indicates
larger, more powerful engines consume more fuel. This factor captures 84% of variance, representing the primary
dimension of vehicle performance.

════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════

Factor 2 (MR2) - Fuel Efficiency Residual (n.s.)
Number of significant loadings: 0
Variance explained: 1.7%
Factor Correlations: MR1 = .03

WARNING: No variables load above cutoff (0.3). Emergency rule applied: using top 2 variable(s) below cutoff for
interpretation.

Variables:
  1. hp, Horsepower (Positive, Weak, .195)
  2. disp, Displacement (Negative, Weak, -.172)

LLM Interpretation:
This factor captures minimal residual variance (1.7%) in the data with no significant loadings above the 0.3 threshold.
Using the emergency rule, horsepower shows the highest loading (.195), suggesting minor fuel consumption patterns
independent of engine size. The near-zero correlation with MR1 (.03) confirms this represents distinct, though
negligible, variance in vehicle characteristics.

Pattern 3: Chat Session (Token-Efficient)

Reuse chat session across analyses to save tokens.

Code
chat <- chat_session(analysis_type = "fa",
                     llm_provider = provider,
                     llm_model = llm)
result1 <- interpret(
  chat_session = chat,
  fit_results = fa_model,
  variable_info = var_info,
  word_limit = 50,
  silent = 1
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating fit summary...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!
Code
result2 <- interpret(
  chat_session = chat,
  fit_results = list(loadings = loadings_matrix, factor_cor_mat = factor_cor_mat),
  variable_info = var_info,
  word_limit = 50,
  silent = 1
)
ℹ Starting fa interpretation...
ℹ Building prompt...
ℹ Querying LLM...
ℹ Parsing LLM response...
ℹ Creating fit summary...
ℹ Building report...
✔ Interpretation complete!

We can check the total global token usage:

Code
print(chat)
Factor Analysis Chat Session
Provider: anthropic
Model: claude-sonnet-4-5
Created: 2025-11-23 13:25:23.888232
Interpretations run: 2
Total tokens - Input: 0 , Output: 0
